metadata.title: How to deploy your first Machine learning models — Part#1 | by Salma El Shahawy | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to deploy your first Machine learning models — Part#1
metadata.description: Develop customized ML pipelines from describing the business problem to deployment. Docker and packaging configurations are included.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: you can also follow the documentation

all_paragraphs: Machine learning models could have tremendous value only when delivered to the end-users. The end-user could be recommender systems in the real-estate platform that suggests properties to renters or investors — Zillow, for instance.
However, machine learning projects can only be successful when a model is deployed, and its predictions are being served.
I was surprised that the machine learning deployment is unusually discussed online — this particular skill you need to learn in the practice workflow.

I tried to google this particular topic, but I found many blog posts about setting Flask APIs for machine learning models. However, none of these tutorials go into detail ahead, developing the only endpoint.

So I decided to blog about this topic in a comprehensive tutorial series on how to deploy ML models into production. I would start by conducting primary statistical analyses using the Jupyter notebook, then building a customized machine learning framework — package. After that, I will develop an endpoint API using FLASK APP. Finally, I would use the CI/CD pipeline to deploy the machine learning model to the Paas Platform.
Some of the technologies we would use are Docker, Gemfury, Flask-API, CircleCI, Kaggle API, and Sklearn. So excited, let’s begin the journey.

Disclaimer, The tutorial is more focused on how things work, not a code line-by-line tutorial. At any point, you can use the Github repo commit history to reference your code and, of course, ask if you need help.
This is a two parts tutorial, this is part one which includes build and publish a machine learning python package. Part two includes building a Flask API end points and deploying to Heroku.

Please note this is an intermediate tutorial, you need to meet certain requirements to be able to catch up. However, I tried to be clear as possible as I can by adding comments and attach resources for further learning and reading.

In Part one , I will walk you through the steps required to develop your own machine learning framework to automate building steps from fetching the dataset to publishing to the cloud so you can download and use.
This tutorial assumes that you have some experience with

In this tutorial, I will use the House price dataset from Kaggle, and it is available for free. I will use it just for demonstration purposes; I would do some raw data processing. You can do more sophisticated analysis; however, I prefer to keep it simple because the main topic is complicated enough. You can check out the complete project in the Github repo.
In this step, We will do the following:
I attached the full details into the Kaggle notebooks and associated the links as follows:

There are plenty of good scaffolding CLI packages that can scaffold a standard structure like pyscaffold and many others to set up the package structure. However, I found it isn’t very comforting for non-software developers background. So I build a scaffold template that makes you worry less about debugging back-end code. You can reference the source code on Github. All you need to do is to clone or download the repo, then follow the instructions to get started.
The package tree structure looks like the following:
It is essential to make your package up and running. We need to set up the files so that packages can predict without any issues. In this step, we would make the following:
Note that we kept the file associated with a version, which makes the work traceable and professional.
10. predict.py obtains the predictions based on the model built. As shown in the terminal, the saved model is versioned, so you can keep track of which model is to choose — logging is fantastic.

For package building, I am going to use the setuptool and wheel dependencies. These allow you to efficiently build and distribute Python packages, especially ones with dependencies on other packages. They can generate a dist source distribution file which has .tar.gz and .whl extension file as well.

All you need to do is to update the setup.py file to set the package metadata. Additionally, you need to update the tox.ini file to include the package building command. It does make sense to execute the package building command after building the model. Once that done, the package is ready to build and install it locally. Running the following command in the terminal:

Now it is going to choose a specific tox environment that is already defined in the tox.ini file. It will create a new virtual environment within the .tox directory. This command would take a longer time in the first execution, so don’t worry!
Now, as shown, the output is pretty different from the previous log of running tox. That’s because it is specifying all the setups done by the setuptools command.
In the terminal, run the following command to install the package locally:
-e tag is to install the package locally, and the . is to specify the root directory of the package.
If you are not in the package directory, you need to specify the package’s path instead of the dot.
Once installed, we can test it by starting the python command line using python.
The package is now successfully installed on your computer and ready to use.

One way to focus only on building efficient models is to automate dataset fetching from known APIs. It is an effective way to ensure you didn’t forget to download the data or place it in the wrong directory. I will make use of the Kaggle API to automate datasets downloads. They have a friendly CLI tool, and it is easy to use and would save you an enormous time downloading the data.
If you tried to run the file, it would throw an error because we didn’t set the API keys yet. We suppose to do that while setting the CircleCI/CD pipeline in the coming steps.

It is imperative to automate the stages of package development. Simultaneously, ensure that if an updated code or a new function has been added, nothing breaks. That’s the point of using the continuous integration/ Deploy and Delivery platforms — CI/CD pipeline. The pipeline ensures everything is working in the flow according to the following chart:
build →Test → Merge → Auto release to public repo → auto deployments
There are plenty of hosted platforms that used to the CI/CD pipelines, to name a few:

I’ve used Travis and Jenkins before, so I was curious to give CircleCI a try for this project. If you’ve ever been involved in any Dev-ops pipeline developments, it has the same actions and nearly the same commands. Although CircleCI has a GitHub integration, it does provide only one free project to build and disable some other features regarding speed and caching during deployment to Paas. However, the configurations almost the same for other hosting platforms.
First, we need to set Kaggle environment variables in the circleci using the following steps:
Open the file that you download for kaggle API token.
Go to the CircleCI dashboard → Project name → Project Settings (at top right corner) → Environment Variables → Add Variable →
and Value to your kaggle username in the JSON file.
repeat the process to add a new variable named KAGGLE_KEY to the value of your secret key.
It is important to name those environment variables the same as above to have a successful build according to the documentation.
I’ve used the getting started guide provided by Circleci documentation; it is pretty easy to follow. What this script is doing is:
I linked to the basic config.yml file at the specific github commit for your reference.
Every time a new git commit pushed to master, CircleCi would run tests, and if it has a successful building, a little green tick would appear near the GitHub corresponding commit.

In this tutorial, I will make the package-private as this would be the situation you would face in real life. However, the steps are almost the same for making the package public. So let’s get started.
These are the steps you need to start with:
CircleCI dashboard → Project name → Project Settings (at top right corner) → Environment Variables → Add Variable →
After replacing full access token and gemfury username with yours, you are all set and ready to the next step — you can also follow the documentation.
4. At this step, you need a shell script to publish the package — publish_model.sh, I followed this code with a little debugging and a lot of reading from here, and here.
Now it is time to update the Circleci config.yml by adding new commands to publish the package.
If you login to your account at gemfury, you would see the package published under the packages tab. Phew!!!
This project is a more intermediate level. We’ve explored many concepts that are needed to include within your skillset. Some of the skills we’ve explored:

Disclaimer: if you navigated to the Github repo, you would notice that I disabled the pytest package — unit tests are disabled. That’s because I wanted to focus on deployment and neglect any issues came up from the unit tests.

Finally, I finished part 1 of how to develop a machine learning python package from scratch. It was an enjoyable and challenging project for me. In part 2, I am going to utilize this package to build the following:
I hope this tutorial gave you a glimpse of the complete lifecycle of a machine learning model. If you have any questions, please ask them; I would love to help! Happy learning!
